Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Crustal Modulation of Flood Basalts--Integrating Field, Geochemical and Computational Data for the Steens Basalts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Flood basalt eruptions are geologically short-lived, catastrophic volcanic events that pour enormous volumes of lava - tens to hundreds of thousands of times greater than the 1980 Mount St Helens eruption? onto Earth's surface. They are important geologic events that completely change the landscape and also have the potential to impact climate and ecosystems. The only flood basalt in the United States is the Columbia River Flood Basalt (CRB), which dominates the landscape in parts of Washington and Oregon. Most of the CRB lavas erupted mainly 16 -15 million years ago and are noted for being among the world's largest individual lava flows. Among the oldest part of the CRB is the Steens Basalt (16.8-16 million years old), which overran 53,000 km2 of land surface in what is now Oregon. The Steens Basalts are compositionally more magnesian than the bulk of the CRB and so provide a unique record of the interaction between mantle-derived basalt and the crust (the outer rocky shell of Earth that extends ~40 km below the surface). At Steens Mountain, in southeastern Oregon, as many as 200 lava flows are spectacularly exposed in a nearly kilometer-thick stack that records how magma (molten rock) changed composition during the earliest stages of the CRB event. Fieldwork at Steens Mountain will yield a temporal (older to younger) sequence of lava samples that will be chemically analyzed using an array of tools. These data will be assessed with a range of computer models, including the latest generation of model called the Magma Chamber Simulator. Modeling results will provide estimates of the amount of new magma added to the crust from the mantle, the ultimate source of the basalt, and also how much crust is incorporated into magma. The sequential sampling allows documentation of how these parameters change with time as the magmatic pulse waxes and wanes. The methodology of combining field and chemical data with computer analysis can be broadly applied to other volcanic terrains, and the results of this study provide a quantitative basis for understanding other large volume magmatic events on Earth.

We hypothesize that the lower Steens Basalt represents magmatism dominated by high rates of magma input during an earlier, energetically waxing stage of magmatism. In contrast, Upper Steens Basalt experienced more interaction with the crust in a thermally waning system, as the locus of CRB activity migrated north and the crustal magmatic system moved to shallower depths in the crust. These hypotheses will be tested by fieldwork, where a representative suite of lava samples will be collected; collection of whole-rock major and trace elements, O-, Sr-, Nd-, Pb-, Hf-, Os- and He-isotopes, petrography and mineral chemistry data; and thermobarometric calculations and other computational petrologic models. Results of this study will allow the petrologic evolution of Steens magmas to be placed in context with mass and thermal exchange that occurred between crust and mantle during the onset of the Columbia River flood basalt event. The broader impacts include (1) involvement of a diverse group of scientists including 2 PIs, 1 PhD student, 2 MS students and several undergraduates. At least 5 are female scientists (including one Latina); (2) development/refinement and presentation of modeling tutorials; (3) scientific outreach in the form of public lectures and field trips; (4) dissemination of results via publications, and conferences; (5) integration of results and rock samples into classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At and near Steens Mountain, in southeast Oregon, up to 1 kilometer of exposure provides access to hundreds of lava flows stacked one on top of the other. These flows are part of a large volcanic event, called a flood basalt, that formed starting about 17 million years ago. This volcanic area, known as Steens Basalt, is the earliest phase of eruption of a larger volcanic event (Columbia River Flood Basalts) that covered much of eastern and central Washington State.

Lava samples collected from the bottom (older) to top (younger) at Steens Mountain/Kiger Gorge allow geologists to document changes in magma (molten rock) composition as the flood basalt event progresses. Changes in abundance and composition of minerals (solids that form as hot magma cools) also provide information about the changing crystallization conditions as volcanism occurs. Magmas with their associated crystals erupt from storage systems that form in the crust, which is a rock layer at and below Earth?s surface. Below the crust is mantle, where many magmas that erupt on to Earth?s surface initially form.

A key question explored in this study was what was the contribution of magma derived from the mantle versus the crust? The mantle typically produces magmas that have higher concentrations of elements such as magnesium and nickel; strontium isotopes, which also provide critical information about the origin of magmas, are typically lower in mantle versus crustal magmas. Based on an array of compositional data, older lava flows, called lower Steens Basalt, were hotter, have more magnesium and nickel, and have lower ratios of strontium isotopes. In contrast, younger lava flows, called upper Steens, were cooler, have lower magnesium and nickel, and have higher strontium isotopes. These results indicate that the early stage of this flood basalt event was dominated by input from the mantle, whereas later, magmas from crust surrounding the magma storage systems were mixed into mantle-derived magmas.

An important part of this research involved testing this hypothesis of changing contribution of mantle and crust using computer programs designed to quantitatively model the masses and temperatures of magmas as they evolve in crustal reservoirs. Results of hundreds of models support the evolution of this magma system from mantle-dominated to increased contribution from crust later in the event. Compositional data and modeling therefore suggest that early in this event, magmas were being pumped into relatively unreactive crust. As hot magmas heated up the crust, crustal rocks began to melt and caused a change in the composition of mantle-derived magmas. This evolution is important not only because it describes the evolution of the magma storage system one of the largest volcanic events on Earth?a flood basalt?but also because a similar progression may be hypothesized for currently active volcanoes. Studies of ancient volcanoes help volcanologists to better understand magma storage systems beneath active volcanoes, which in turn, helps improve volcanic hazard assessment.

Of particular interest in the Steens Basalt are crystals called plagioclase. Plagioclase at Steens is abundant (making up to 40% of the lava flow volume) and large (up to 5 centimeters). The origin(s) of these crystals are important for understanding the magma storage system and have worldwide significance because many other volcanic provinces have large and abundant plagioclase, suggesting similar formation conditions.

Detailed compositional data collected on plagioclase crystals from Steens lava flows show that lower Steens plagioclase typically has lower concentrations of key elements such as barium and lower strontium isotope ratios. Another important result is the strontium isotope ratio of the crystal is typically the same as that of the surrounding volcanic material, called groundmass. In contrast, upper Steens plagioclase typically has higher barium, higher strontium isotopes ratios, and more of the crystals have strontium isotope values that differ from adjacent groundmass. Groundmass represents, upon eruption, molten magma that cools and surrounds plagioclase. These data suggest that lower Steens plagioclase, not typically found in hotter magmas, forms because previously crystallized plagioclase, which resides in mushy piles in the magma storage system, is swept into lower Steens magmas. The hypothesis is that plagioclase reacts with hot magma and resorbs. Upon cooling, new plagioclase forms. Upper Steens magmas also entrain plagioclase, but because these magmas are cooler, only some of the plagioclase resorbs. Thus, both ?old? and ?new? plagioclase are present.

This hypothesis of entrained plagioclase is supported by detailed computer modeling. Entrained crystals are produced computationally by cooling Steens magma, which causes plagioclase to form. This plagioclase is then added to lower and upper Steens magmas and computationally reacts. Model results show that all of the plagioclase resorbs in hotter lower Steens magmas, and upon 15-20 degrees C of cooling, starts to crystallize. Upper Steens plagioclase only partially resorbs, and cooling also causes new plagioclase to form. This hypothesis can be tested at other locations on Earth where large and abundant plagioclase are present.
